chapter.title: LD are based in the brain
chapter.content:
LD are based in the brain

We’ve examined the first of our 6 consensus statements. Let’s move on to our second consensus statement. “LD are neurologically based and intrinsic to the individual.”

Although difficult to measure, LD are neurologically based and intrinsic to the individual. This means that the disability is based in the brain.  For example, researchers, through the use of functional MRI, are able to see differences in the brain functioning of individuals who are normal readers and those who are poor readers. 

 

Images from: Focus on Basics (August 2001) The Neurobiology of Reading and Dyslexia, by Sally E. Shaywitz, M.D., and  Bennett A. Shaywitz, M.D.

chapter.title: Early, ongoing interventions can have positive effects
chapter.content:
Early, ongoing interventions can have positive effects

Research is also showing that early and ongoing reading interventions can positively affect brain functioning and associated reading skills.

chapter.title: ﻿More information on brain research
chapter.content:
More information on brain research

While neuroscientific research is deepening our understanding of LD, it is just beginning to offer us practical information in terms of diagnosis and teaching. More information on brain research and its implications for adults with LD can be found in the LINCS Learning Disabilities and Neuroscience module of the Learning to Achieve online learning series.
